title_en: Publishes 'Maxwell Speed Distribution' (Kinetic Theory of Gases)

summary.text_en: James Clerk Maxwell published his landmark paper 'Illustrations of the Dynamical Theory of Gases'. In it, he introduced probability theory to the study of gas molecules. He derived the famous 'Maxwell Distribution Law', a mathematical formula describing the proportion of molecules moving at various speeds at a given temperature (how many are fast, how many are slow). This was the first 'statistical law' in the history of physics, precisely linking macroscopic 'temperature' to the 'average speed' of microscopic molecules.

key_points_en: The first 'statistical law' in physics history
Derived the distribution curve of molecular speeds (Bell curve)
Defined temperature as a measure of 'average kinetic energy'
Laid the foundation for the 'Kinetic Theory of Gases'

story.text_en: Before Maxwell, scientists (like Clausius) accepted gases were molecules but often assumed they all moved at the 'same' average speed. Maxwell realized this was unrealistic; collisions would speed some up and slow others down. He brilliantly applied 'social statistics' (math used for mortality rates) to physics. He calculated that while you can't know the speed of a *single* molecule, for *billions* of them, the speeds would form a stable, asymmetrical 'bell curve'. This meant at any moment, a tiny few are stopped, and a tiny few are super-fast. This was the first time physics admitted 'determinism' wasn't enough; 'probability' was the truth.

fun_facts.text_en: This law explains why water 'evaporates' even at room temperature (without boiling): according to the distribution curve, there is always a small fraction of 'super-fast' molecules with enough energy to escape the surface.
Maxwell was inspired to apply this math to molecules after reading the work of astronomer Adolphe Quetelet on the statistics of 'human characteristics' (like height).

simple_explanation.text_en:
Imagine a playground full of kids running wildly (gas molecules). Some are fast, some are slow, and they keep bumping into each other.
If you ask, 'How fast is Johnny running?', it's impossible to say, because he'll bump into someone and slow down in a second.
But Maxwell drew a chart that says: 'No matter how much they bump, there will *always* be 5% running super fast, 10% super slow, and most (60%) running at medium speed.'
That chart is the Maxwell Distribution. If you turn up the heat, the whole chart shifts rightâ€”meaning 'most kids' are now running faster.

applications.text_en: Only molecules with energy above a certain 'threshold' (activation energy) can react. The Maxwell distribution calculates exactly what percentage of molecules meet this criteria.

applications.title: è¡Œæ˜Ÿå¤§æ°”å±‚
applications.text_en: It explains why the Moon has no atmosphere: its gravity is too weak to hold onto the 'super-fast' molecules at the tail end of the Maxwell distribution, so they all escaped over time.

impact.text_en: This was a massive leap in physics methodology. Maxwell proved that for complex systems, we don't need to know the fate of every particle, only their 'statistical laws'. This idea directly laid the foundation for Boltzmann's 'Statistical Mechanics' (`boltzmann_statistical_mechanics_1877`) and ultimately led to the probabilistic interpretation of Quantum Mechanics.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Clausius (he introduced the concept of 'mean free path', which was the basis for Maxwell's derivation)
Daniel Bernoulli (proposed the basic idea that 'gas pressure is caused by molecular impacts' back in 1738)

influenced.contribution_en: Ludwig Boltzmann (he generalized Maxwell's distribution and built the complete framework of Statistical Mechanics)
(Himself) Maxwell's Demon (this thought experiment was based entirely on his understanding of the uneven distribution of molecular speeds)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Maxwell introduced 'probability' into physics, half a century before quantum mechanics.

quiz.question_en: According to Maxwell's Speed Distribution law, what happens to the speed of molecules when the 'temperature' of a gas increases?
options_en: All molecules move at exactly the same speed
The average speed increases, and the distribution curve becomes 'wider and flatter'
quiz.explanation_en: Temperature is a measure of average kinetic energy. As temperature rises, the average speed increases, and the 'spread' of speeds also gets wider (some very fast, some still slow), causing the curve to shift right and flatten out.
